privacyLaws.lawName: Alabama Data Breach Notification Act of 2018
privacyLaws.description: The Alabama Data Breach Notification Act of 2018 is a legislative measure aimed at protecting the personal information of Alabama residents and establishing procedures for notifying individuals and appropriate authorities in the event of a data breach

The development, implementation, and maintenance of an information security program about the extent of its operations and the sensitivity of the non-public information under its ownership, custody, or control are requirements for covered entities licensed by the Alabama Department of Insurance.

The Alabama Right of Publicity Act aims to protect individuals' interests in controlling the commercial exploitation of their identity and provides legal recourse for unauthorized use by third parties.

The Alaska Personal Information Protection Act (APIPA) is a law that provides several protections for personal information. These are: requiring entities to notify customers if there is a breach of personal information, granting customers the ability to put a freeze on their credit report for security, restrictions on the use of social security numbers, regulations pertaining to the disposal of records containing personal information, allowing victims of identity theft to petition the court for a determination of factual innocence, and a requirement of truncated payment card information on sales receipts.

privacyLaws.lawName: California Online Privacy Protection Act of 2003 (CalOPPA)
privacyLaws.description: The California Online Privacy Protection Act (CalOPPA) is a state law designed to safeguard the privacy of individuals who use websites and online services. Enacted in 2003, CalOPPA mandates that operators of commercial websites and online services that collect personally identifiable information (PII) from California residents must conspicuously post a privacy policy on their websites. This policy must detail the types of information collected, how it's used, and whether it's shared with third parties.

personalDataCategories: Any other identifier that permits the physical or online contacting of a specific individual

Information concerning a user that the Web site or online service collects online from the user and maintains in personally identifiable form in combination with an identifier described in this subdivision.

dataTransfer.description: Identify the categories of personally identifiable information that the operator collects through the Web site or online service about individual consumers who use or visit its commercial Web site or online service and the categories of third-party persons or entities with whom the operator may share that personally identifiable information.

exemptions.description: Non-commercial websites in California are exempt from CalOPPA.

enforcementAuthority: The State of California Department of Justice
finingAuthority: The Consumer Privacy Fund within the General Fund of the state
penalties: If you fail to comply within the 30-day grace period, you face a maximum penalty of $2,500 per violation.
personalLiability: An operator shall be in violation of this subdivision only if the operator fails to post its policy within 30 days after being notified of noncompliance.

otherPrivacyLaws.description: The California Invasion of Privacy Act (CIPA) is a state law enacted to protect individuals from various forms of invasions of privacy. The CIPA prohibits the unauthorized recording, eavesdropping, or monitoring of confidential communications, including conversations held in private places, without the consent of all parties involved.

The California Shine the Light Law, enacted in 2003 and amended in subsequent years, is designed to enhance transparency and consumer awareness regarding the sharing of their personal information with third parties for direct marketing purposes. This law requires businesses that have customer relationships with California residents to disclose upon request, free of charge, the categories of personal information shared and the identities of any third parties with whom the information was shared for direct marketing purposes in the preceding calendar year.

The Confidentiality of Medical Information Act (CMIA) is a California state law enacted to safeguard the privacy and confidentiality of patients' medical information. Established to address concerns surrounding the unauthorized disclosure of sensitive health data, CMIA imposes strict regulations on healthcare providers, health plans, and contractors who handle medical information.

otherPrivacyLaws.lawName: Patient Access to Health Records Act (PAHRA)
otherPrivacyLaws.description: The California Patient Access to Health Records Act (PAHRA) is a state law enacted to empower patients with greater control over their medical information.

The California Financial Information Privacy Act (CALFIPA) is legislation aimed at safeguarding the privacy of individuals' financial information. Enacted to protect consumers' sensitive financial data, CALFIPA imposes requirements on financial institutions operating in California.
Outlines protections and requirements regarding employee data.

otherPrivacyLaws.lawName: Privacy Rights for California Minors in the Digital World Act (Eraser Law)
otherPrivacyLaws.description: The Privacy Rights for California Minors in the Digital World Act, commonly known as the Eraser Law, is legislation aimed at protecting the online privacy of minors in California. Enacted in 2015, this law requires operators of websites, online services, and mobile applications directed at minors or knowingly collecting personal information from them to allow minors to request the removal of content they have posted.

privacyLaws.description: Colorado is the third US state to enact comprehensive data privacy legislation. Colorado Governor Jared Polis signed the Colorado Privacy Act (CPA) into law on July 7, 2021, with an effective date of July 1, 2023. The statute strives to preserve Colorado residents' privacy. Once in effect, the new Colorado privacy law will oblige certain organizations who do business or manufacture products for Colorado citizens to provide specific personal data privacy protections.

notice.description: A controller shall provide consumers with a reasonably accessible, clear and meaningful privacy notice that includes several key elements: firstly, it must outline the categories of personal data processed by the controller. Secondly, it should elucidate the purposes for which personal data is being processed. Thirdly, consumers should be informed about how they can exercise their rights, including the process for appealing a decision made by the controller regarding their request. Additionally, the notice should delineate the categories of personal data shared with third parties, if any, as well as the specific categories of those third parties. Lastly, the controller must provide an active electronic mail address or another online mechanism through which consumers can reach out to them.

purposeLimitation.description: A controller shall not process personal data for purposes that are neither reasonably necessary to, nor compatible with, the disclosed purposes for which such personal data is processed, as disclosed to the consumer.

dataMinimization.description: A controller shall limit the collection of personal data to what is adequate, relevant and reasonably necessary in relation to the purposes for which such data is processed, as disclosed to the consumer.

securityReqs.description: A controller shall establish, implement and maintain reasonable administrative, technical and physical data security practices to protect the confidentiality, integrity and accessibility of personal data appropriate to the volume and nature of the personal data at issue.

processorReqs.description: A processor must comply with the instructions provided by the controller and assist them in meeting their obligations outlined in the relevant sections of the act. This assistance includes implementing appropriate technical and organizational measures to respond to consumer rights requests, ensuring the security of processing personal data, and providing necessary information for data protection assessments. Contracts between controllers and processors must detail data processing procedures and include instructions for processing data, confidentiality obligations, data deletion or return at the end of services, and engagement of subcontractors. Processors must also facilitate assessments by the controller or designated assessors and provide reports upon request. Importantly, this section clarifies that both controllers and processors remain liable for their respective roles in data processing relationships. Additionally, it distinguishes between controllers and processors based on their actions and responsibilities in specific data processing activities.

riskImpact.description: Controllers must conduct and document a data protection assessment for each processing activity that poses a heightened risk of harm to consumers. Such activities include processing for targeted advertising, sale of personal data, profiling with foreseeable risks of harm, and processing sensitive data. The assessment must weigh the benefits to the controller, consumers, and other stakeholders against potential risks, considering safeguards to mitigate these risks.

privateRightOfAction: Nothing in sections 1 to 10, inclusive, of this act shall be construed as providing the basis for, or be subject to, a private right of action for violations of said sections or any other law.

notice.description: A controller shall provide consumers with a reasonably accessible, clear, and meaningful privacy notice that includes six key components. Firstly, it should outline the categories of personal data that the controller processes. Secondly, it must clarify the purpose for which personal data is being processed. Thirdly, it should elucidate how consumers can exercise their rights, including the process for appealing a decision made by the controller regarding their request. Fourthly, the notice should specify the categories of personal data that the controller shares with third parties, if any. Fifthly, it must disclose the categories of third parties with whom the controller shares personal data, if applicable. Lastly, the notice must provide an active electronic mail address or another online mechanism through which consumers can contact the controller for inquiries or concerns regarding their personal data.

purposeLimitation.description: Except as otherwise permitted by this chapter, not process personal data for purposes that are neither reasonably necessary to, nor compatible with, the disclosed purposes for which such personal data is processed, as disclosed to the consumer, unless the controller obtains the consumer’s consent.

dataMinimization.description: Limit the collection of personal data to what is adequate, relevant, and reasonably necessary in relation to the purposes for which such data is processed, as disclosed to the consumer.

securityReqs.description: Establish, implement, and maintain reasonable administrative, technical, and physical data security practices to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and accessibility of personal data appropriate to the volume and nature of the personal data at issue.

processorReqs.description: Processors must adhere to several requirements. Firstly, they must implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to assist controllers in responding to consumer rights requests. Secondly, processors are tasked with aiding controllers in ensuring the security of processing personal data and in notifying the controller of any breaches of security. Thirdly, processors must provide necessary information to enable controllers to conduct and document data protection assessments. Additionally, contracts between controllers and processors must govern the data processing procedures, outlining instructions for processing data, the nature and purpose of processing, the type of data subject to processing, and the duration of processing. Furthermore, processors must ensure confidentiality, delete or return personal data to the controller upon request, provide information to demonstrate compliance with obligations, engage subcontractors as per controller's direction, and allow for assessments of their compliance.

riskImpact.description: A controller that manages or handles the data of at least 100,000 consumers, excluding data specifically processed for payment transactions, is required to conduct and document regular data protection assessments for each processing activity that poses an elevated risk of harm to consumers. These assessments are necessary for activities such as processing data for targeted advertising, selling personal data, or conducting profiling that could lead to unfair treatment or unlawful discrimination against consumers.

dataTransfer.description: Sale of personal data does not include the disclosure or transfer of personal data to an affiliate of the controller or The disclosure or transfer of personal data to a third party as an asset that is part of a merger, acquisition, bankruptcy, or other similar transaction in which the third party assumes control of all or part of the controller’s assets, or a proposed merger, acquisition, bankruptcy, or other similar transaction in which the third party assumes control of all or part of the controller’s assets.

processorReqs.description: The duties of a processor under the specified legislation outline the responsibilities to adhere to the instructions of a controller and assist in meeting the controller's obligations, including responding to consumer rights requests, ensuring the security of processing personal data, and providing necessary information for data protection assessments. A contract between the controller and processor must specify processing procedures, data types, duration, rights, and obligations, including confidentiality obligations, data deletion or return, information sharing for compliance demonstration, and engagement of subcontractors. The processor may arrange for independent assessments of compliance and must provide reports to the controller upon request. privacyLaws.description: Senate Bill 5's Indiana Consumer Data Protection Act (Indiana CDPA) safeguards the rights to privacy and personal information of the state's 6.8 million citizens and imposes data privacy obligations on businesses operating in the state or offering products or services to residents.

personalDataCategories: A mental or physical health diagnosis made by a health care provider

individualRights.name: Right to Know if a controller is processing the consumer’s personal information
Right to Opt Out of targeted advertising, sale of personal data, profiling, or automated decision making

notice.description: A controller shall provide consumers with a reasonably accessible, clear, and meaningful privacy notice that includes the types or categories of personal data that the controller processes. It should elucidate the reasons or purposes for which the controller processes the personal data of consumers. he notice must outline how consumers can exercise their rights under the applicable regulations, including the process for appealing a decision made by the controller regarding a consumer's request. Consumers should be informed about the categories or types of personal data that the controller shares with third parties, if any. And additionally, the notice should specify the categories or types of third parties with whom the controller shares consumers' personal data.

purposeLimitation.description: Personal data processed by a controller for purposes authorized under the relevant chapter cannot be utilized for any other purpose unless permitted elsewhere in the legislation. Such processing must adhere to specific criteria: it must be reasonably necessary and proportionate to the authorized purpose, and it must be adequate, relevant, and limited to what is essential for that purpose. Additionally, personal data collected, used, or retained must consider the nature and purpose of such actions, and must be safeguarded by reasonable administrative, technical, and physical measures to protect its confidentiality, integrity, and accessibility, while also mitigating foreseeable risks of harm to consumers. If a controller processes personal data under an exemption provided by the legislation, the controller must demonstrate that the processing qualifies for the exemption and complies with the requirements outlined in this section.

securityReqs.description: A controller shall establish, implement, and maintain reasonable administrative, technical, and physical data security practicesto protectthe confidentiality, integrity, and accessibility of personal data. The data security practices required under this subdivision must be appropriate to the volume and nature of the personal data at issue.

processorReqs.description: A processor must comply with the instructions provided by a controller and assist the controller in fulfilling its obligations under the chapter. This assistance includes aiding the controller in responding to consumer requests, ensuring the security of processing personal data, notifying the controller of security breaches, and providing necessary information for data protection impact assessments. Additionally, a contract between a controller and a processor must govern the processor's data processing procedures, specifying instructions for processing personal data, the nature and purpose of processing, data subject to processing, duration of processing, and rights and obligations of both parties. The contract must ensure confidentiality of data processing, deletion or return of personal data at the end of service provision, provision of information for demonstrating compliance, cooperation with assessments, and engagement of subcontractors subject to contractual obligations.

riskImpact.description: Data protection impact assessments conducted under this chapter shall identify and weigh the benefits that may flow, directly and indirectly,from the processing to the controller, the consumer, other stakeholders, and the public against the potential risks to the rights of the consumer associated with such processing, as mitigated by safeguards that can be employed by the controller to reduce such risks

dataTransfer.description: Sale of personal does not include the disclosure or transfer of personal data to an affiliate of the controller or the disclosure or transfer of personal data to a third party as an asset that is part of a proposed or actual merger, acquisition, bankruptcy, or other transaction in which the third party assumes control of all or part of the controller's assets

privacyLaws.description: The New Jersey Data Protection Act (NJDPA) gives people of New Jersey authority over their personal data. It also gives certain rights and places requirements on those that handle and control consumer data. The legislation is applicable to companies and organizations that operate within the state or that create goods or services intended for New Jersey residents.

personalDataCategories: Mental or physical health condition, treatment, or diagnosis
Status as a transgender or nonbinary person
Genetic or biometric data that may be process for identifying an individual
Personal data collected from a known child

individualRights.name: Right to Know if a controller is processing the consumer’s personal information
Right to Opt Out of Targeted Advertising, sale of personal information, or automated profiling

notice.description: A controller is obligated to furnish consumers with a comprehensive and easily accessible privacy notice that must contain specific information. This notice should encompass details such as the categories of personal data processed by the controller, the purposes for which the data is processed, and the identities of any third parties with whom the data may be shared. Additionally, it should outline any categories of personal data shared with third parties, if applicable, and provide instructions on how consumers can exercise their rights, including contact information for the controller and avenues for appealing decisions regarding consumer requests. Furthermore, the notice must elucidate the process for notifying consumers of significant changes to the provided information and specify an active electronic mail address or other online mechanism for consumer inquiries.

purposeLimitation.description: A controller shall not process personal data for purposes that are neither reasonably necessary to, nor compatible with, the purposes for which such personal data is processed, as disclosed to the consumer.

dataMinimization.description: A controller shall limit the collection of personal data to what is adequate, relevant, and reasonably necessary in relation to the purposes for which such data is processed, as disclosed to the consumer.

securityReqs.description: A controller shall take reasonable measures to establish, implement, and maintain administrative, technical, and physical data security practices to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and accessibility of personal data and to secure personal data during both storage and use from unauthorized acquisition. The data security practices shall be appropriate to the volume and nature of the personal data at issue.

processorReqs.description: Processors are required to comply with the instructions of the controller and assist them in fulfilling their obligations. This assistance includes implementing appropriate technical and organizational measures to respond to consumer requests, ensuring data security, and providing necessary information for data protection assessments. Processors must also maintain confidentiality and engage subcontractors under written contracts that uphold the processor's obligations. Contracts between controllers and processors must detail processing instructions, types of data processed, duration of processing, and compliance requirements. Processors must also facilitate the controller's ability to demonstrate compliance and allow for assessments or inspections. Additionally, contracts cannot absolve either party of their liabilities under the legislation.

riskImpact.description: Controllers are required to conduct and document data protection assessments for processing activities involving personal data that pose a heightened risk of harm to consumers. These assessments must evaluate the benefits of the processing against potential risks to consumer rights, considering factors such as the use of de-identified data, consumer expectations, and the controller-consumer relationship. Controllers must make these assessments available to the Division of Consumer Affairs upon request, and the division may review them for compliance with the law. Data protection assessments are confidential and exempt from public inspection. Heightened risk activities include targeted advertising, profiling with foreseeable risks of harm, selling personal data, and processing sensitive data.

exemptions.description: Data subject to the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) and the Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act (HITECH)
Financial institution or an affiliate of a financial institution governed by, or personal data collected, processed, sold, or disclosed in accordance with the GLBA
The secondary market institutions identified in 15 U.S.C. s.6809(3)(D) and 12 C.F.R. s.1016.3(l)(3)(iii)
An individual, firm, association, corporation, or other entity that is licensed in this state as an insurance company and transacts insurance business
The sale of a consumer’s personally identifiable information by the New Jersey Motor Vehicle Commission that is permitted by the federal Drivers' Privacy Protection Act of 1994.

exemptions.type: Personal information covered by the Fair Credit Reporting Act
exemptions.description: Personally identifiable information collected, processed, sold, or disclosed by a consumer reporting agency, as defined in 15 U.S.C. s.1681a(f), if the collection, processing, sale, or disclosure of the personally identifiable information is limited by the federal “Fair Credit Reporting Act,” 15 U.S.C. s.1681 et seq., and implementing regulations.

enforcementAuthority: The Office of the Attorney General
rulemakingAuthority: The Division of Consumer Affairs in the Department of Law and Public Safety
finingAuthority: The Office of the Attorney General
penalties: No monetary amount is defined in the law’s text, but a violation of the NJDPA will constitute a violation of the New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act, which can entail fines of up to $10,000 for the initial violation and up to $20,000 for subsequent violations.
privateRightOfAction: No provision within the bill can be interpreted as establishing or allowing for a private right of action for violations of the legislation.

control or process the personal data of at least 25,000 consumers and the controller derives revenue, or receives a discount on the price of any goods or services, from the sale of personal data.

notice.description: A controller is required to provide a privacy notice that is easily accessible, clear, and meaningful to consumers. This comprehensive notice aims to inform consumers about how their personal information is handled and shared by the controller.

The Utah Consumer Privacy Act is a legislative measure designed to protect the privacy rights of individuals within the state of Utah. It establishes clear definitions for terms related to personal data and grants consumers several important rights, including the ability to access and delete certain personal data held by businesses, as well as the right to opt out of data collection and usage for specific purposes.

individualRights.name: Right to Know if a controller is processing the consumer’s personal information

notice.description: Controllers are required to offer consumers a privacy notice that is reasonably accessible and clear, containing specific information such as the categories of personal data processed, the purposes for processing, and instructions on how consumers can exercise their rights. Additionally, if a controller sells consumers' personal data to third parties or engages in targeted advertising, they must explicitly disclose to consumers how they can opt out of such practices.

lawfulBasis.description: A violation of this chapter does not provide a basis for, nor is a violation of this chapter subject to, a private right of action under this chapter or any other law.

securityReqs.description: A controller shall establish, implement, and maintain reasonable administrative, technical, and physical data security practices designed to: protect the confidentiality and integrity of personal data; and reduce reasonably foreseeable risks of harm to consumers relating to the processing of personal data.

processorReqs.description: Processors are mandated to strictly adhere to the instructions provided by the controller regarding data processing activities. Additionally, processors are obligated to assist controllers in meeting their obligations, particularly those related to the security of processing personal data and the notification of any security breaches. Before engaging in any processing activities on behalf of a controller, processors and controllers must enter into a contract that clearly delineates instructions for data processing, the nature and purpose of the processing, data subject details, processing duration, and the rights and obligations of both parties. Furthermore, this contract must mandate that processors ensure confidentiality among personnel handling personal data and engage any subcontractors under written agreements that impose identical obligations regarding the protection of personal data.

riskImpact.description: A controller shall establish, implement, and maintain reasonable administrative, technical, and physical data security practices designed to: protect the confidentiality and integrity of personal data; and reduce reasonably foreseeable risks of harm to consumers relating to the processing of personal data.

individualRights.name: Right to Know if a controller is processing the consumer’s personal information

notice.description: Controllers shall provide consumers with a reasonably accessible, clear, and meaningful privacy notice.

purposeLimitation.description: A controller shall limit the collection of personal data to what is adequate, relevant, and reasonably necessary in relation to the purposes for which such data is processed, as disclosed to the consumer

securityReqs.description: A controller shall establish, implement, and maintain reasonable administrative, technical, and physical data security practices to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and accessibility of personal data. Such data security practices shall be appropriate to the volume and nature of the personal data at issue

processorReqs.description: Processors are required to adhere to the instructions provided by the controller and assist the controller in fulfilling its obligations under the relevant legislation. This assistance includes responding to consumer rights requests, ensuring the security of processing personal data, and notifying the controller of any breaches of security. Additionally, processors must enter into a contract with the controller that governs the processing procedures. This contract should clearly outline instructions for processing data, including confidentiality obligations, data deletion or return procedures, and cooperation with assessments. The processor is also responsible for engaging subcontractors under written contracts that impose similar obligations.

riskImpact.description: Controllers are mandated to conduct and document data protection assessments for specific processing activities involving personal data. These activities include targeted advertising, sale of personal data, profiling with foreseeable risks to consumers, processing of sensitive data, and any activities posing heightened risks to consumers. During these assessments, controllers must weigh the benefits of processing against potential risks to consumer rights, considering factors such as the use of de-identified data, consumer expectations, and the nature of the controller-consumer relationship.
